bounds.description: Puget Sound / Salish Sea, Washington State

species.name: Orca
species.source: NOAA Fisheries ESA listing 2005; SRKW Recovery Plan
species.fact: Only 73 individuals remain. They communicate in dialects unique to each pod, passed between generations.

species.name: Orca
species.commonName: Southern Resident Killer Whale — L Pod
species.source: NOAA SRKW monitoring; Strait of Juan de Fuca sightings database
species.fact: L Pod is the largest resident pod. Members sometimes range to the outer Pacific coast.

species.name: Harbor Porpoise
species.source: Cascadia Research; WDFW Marine Mammal Investigations
species.fact: Echolocates at 130 kHz — among the highest frequencies of any cetacean. Rarely seen; more often heard.

species.name: Harbor Seal
species.source: WDFW Pinniped Haul-out Survey; Hood Canal monitoring program
species.fact: ~11,000 in Puget Sound. Can dive to 300m and hold breath for 30 minutes. Pups born on beaches in June.

species.name: Steller Sea Lion
species.source: NOAA Fisheries; seasonal haul-out sites at Protection Island
species.fact: Winter visitors from Alaska. Males can reach 1,100 kg. Roost on navigation buoys and rock outcroppings.

species.name: Giant Pacific Octopus
species.source: WDFW dive surveys; Puget Sound Nearshore Ecosystem Restoration Project
species.fact: World's largest octopus — arm span to 4.3m. Lives in dens, hunts at night. Lifespan: only 3–5 years.

species.name: Market Squid
species.source: WDFW spawn surveys; Puget Sound mid-channel trawl data
species.fact: Schools of thousands bioluminesce blue-green during spawning. Each individual lives less than one year.

species.name: Eelgrass
species.source: NERR Padilla Bay; WDFW SAV mapping 2022 — 8,000 acres documented
species.fact: Padilla Bay holds the largest eelgrass bed in Washington — 8,000 acres. Nursery for juvenile Chinook salmon.

species.name: Eelgrass
species.source: WDFW SAV; Nisqually Delta restoration monitoring 2009–2023
species.fact: Each acre sequesters carbon at 35× the rate of a tropical rainforest. The Nisqually bed was restored from farmland in 2009.

species.name: Bull Kelp
species.source: WDFW Kelp Canopy Survey 2022; MRC of the Salish Sea
species.fact: Grows up to 10cm per day. Canopy forests shelter 800+ species. San Juan beds are among the densest remaining.

species.name: Bull Kelp
species.source: WDFW Kelp Survey: Hood Canal 40% canopy loss 1990–2022
species.fact: Hood Canal has lost 40% of its kelp canopy since 1990. Warming waters and low-oxygen events are the primary cause.

species.name: Chinook Salmon
species.source: NOAA ESA listing 1999; Puget Sound Salmon Recovery Plan
species.fact: Primary prey of Southern Resident Orcas. Their decline drives orca starvation. Listed under ESA since 1999.

species.name: Coho Salmon
species.source: NOAA ESA listing; Puget Sound coho ESU recovery plan
species.fact: Urban tire rubber chemical 6PPD-quinone is lethal to coho within hours of rain runoff. A leading cause of collapse.

species.name: Pacific Herring
species.source: WDFW Spawn Survey: Cherry Point largest US West Coast aggregation
species.fact: Cherry Point aggregation is the largest Pacific herring spawn on the US West Coast. Base of the entire Salish Sea food web.

species.name: Dungeness Crab
species.source: WDFW Crab Survey; Puget Sound subtidal monitoring
species.fact: Migrate seasonally between shallow spawning grounds and deep overwintering sites. Molt annually, leaving ghost shells.

species.name: Geoduck
species.source: WDFW Geoduck Survey; Puget Sound aquaculture assessment
species.fact: Can live 168 years — the oldest found was 179. Buried up to 1m deep. Filter feeders critical to water clarity.
